description:
Final Strike is a competitive deck forging game, where players strategize for position, fighting for the glory of defeating enemies and earning the glory that comes with dealing - the Final Strike.

All players start with the same starting deck, and will shuffle and draw a hand of 5 cards to begin the game. On any given players turn, players MUST play one weapon on their turn - dealing that weapons damage to a monster and collecting that much blood from their target (knowing that every 4 points of blood will be turned into 1 point of Glory at the end of the game, and the player with the most glory at the end of the game being the winner!)

The player can choose to play a stronger weapon that deals more damage, or use a "Magic Hammer" that deals only 1 damage, in order to forge a weapon from their discard pile, destroying it and gaining a new more powerful weapon from the blacksmith - a randomized market of weapons, ranging from strong re-occurring played effects, ongoing field abilities, or the tactics to deal extra damage when that weapon is shuffled from a discard pile back into their deck!

While dealing damage is one way to victory, true 'glory' can be found by dealing the 'Final Strike', aka removing the last point of blood from an enemy - earning the reward listed on the bottom of that foe.

The game progress over three 'Act"s with each act ending when the boss for that act is defeated - where as all players will then wash off all their blood (converting them into glory at that time.)

After the Act 3 boss has been defeated and the final rewards have been tallied - the player with the most glory, is deemed the winner of Final Strike!

—description from the designer

Roar The Card Game puts you in charge of your very own dinosaur park. In this 2-4 player game you will compete against other players to build the best dinosaur park over the Cretaceous, Jurassic, and Triassic periods. But watch out an extinction event can disrupt your plans at any moment, and dinosaurs running around outside of your park are bad business.

—description from the designer

Alter is a 52 card deck game of strategy, bluffing, and a bit of luck. Count the value of your cards to get to 21, but can you get there when the value of your cards change?

The value of cards can be changed with either an "Alter" or "Revert" card. The object of the game is to reach 21 by the beginning of your turn, meaning even if you have 21 points it can still change.

You can either try to win by getting to 21, or outlast all the other players until the deck runs out and highest score wins.

Card values are kept track of by a card counter and tokens, which are provided with the game.

—description from the publisher

W grze Spy Guy stajesz siÄ™ detektywem, próbujÄ…cym znaleÅºÄ‡ osobÄ™ odpowiedzialnÄ… za seriÄ™ przestÄ™pstw przeciwko mieszkaÅ„com miasta. ZnajdÅº na mapie jak najwiÄ™cej wskazówek, które pomogÄ… Ci znaleÅºÄ‡ zÅ‚oczyÅ„cÄ™ zanim ucieknie z miasta. Spy Guy to gra kooperacyjna, która sprawdza Twoje umiejÄ™tnoÅ›ci obserwacji i wspóÅ‚pracy miÄ™dzy graczami. Na jednej metrowej planszy Treflikowa szukajcie wskazówek, które przybliÅ¼Ä… Was do odnalezienia sprawcy. JeÅ›li uda Ci siÄ™ dogoniÄ‡ Doktora Moritza, wygrywasz grÄ™!

In Spy Guy you become a detective trying to find the person responsible for a series of crimes against people of your city. Find on the map as many clues as possible, which will help you find villain before he flee the city. Spy Guy is a cooperative game that tests your observation skills and collaboration between players. On one meter board of Treflikowo look for clues, which would bring you closer to find perpetrator. If you manage to catch up to Doktor Moritze you win the game!

In dem Spiel Spy Guy wirst du ein Detektiv, der versucht, die Person zu finden, die für eine Reihe von Verbrechen gegen die Bewohner deiner Stadt verantwortlich ist. Finde so viele Hinweise wie möglich auf der Karte, damit du den Bösewicht finden kannst, bevor er aus der Stadt flieht. Spy Guy ist ein kooperatives Spiel, das deine Beobachtungsgabe und die Zusammenarbeit zwischen den Spielern testet. Suchen Sie auf dem ein Meter hohen Treflikow-Brett nach Hinweisen, die Sie dem Täter näher bringen.Wenn du es schaffst, Dr. Moritz einzuholen, hast du das Spiel gewonnen!

A mysterious incident in the small town of Dennsberg! During a climbing tour on the Talbachhorn, Thomas Borgmann, Managing Director of the traditional soup manufacturer BORGMANN's, fell from a height of several meters. The local police department believes it was a tragic accident. But there are signs that point in a different direction...

Your criminalistic skills are required! As a team of experienced investigators, you know exactly what you have to do: Research, discuss, combine – and solve this mysterious case together!

Choose a Chef, each with their own special ability: build cheese machines, collect ingredients to make the cheese and burn down your competitors factories with cheese fires!

Manage your hand of ingredients and build the most effective cheese factory.

The first player to make 20 points worth of cheese.

Backscore is a perfect-information game played on a 7x11 grid, in which each player controls a five-piece team and coach in a heavily abstracted sport scenario.  Points are scored by moving a neutral 'ball' piece back into a section of one's own back row, having pieces kick it about.

Play is progressive - that is, the first player moves one piece, the second moves two, and thereafter each turn involves moving three pieces.  Moves are 'slides', much like a queen in chess, but each piece must move as far as possible - meaning that the challenges of the game are less about speed (action is quick and can range rapidly around the board), and more about strategizing to keep good control over one's pieces and setting up good positionings.

Backscore is a more-complex descendant (different enough that it escapes being a plain variant, but close enough credit is important to give) of Neutron by Robert Krauss.

—description from the designer

Your objective is to fully occupy 3 Empires in addition to your own.

This game in the RisiKo! family of games is markedly different to the original RisiKo! as it has no territory cards, and players do not get armies based on the total number of individual territories, but instead for controlling regions, banners and castles.

The different cards in the game act as combat modifiers: Allow for players to carry on attacks that are otherwise not permitted, get reinforcement armies, force temporarily non-aggression pacts or look at another player's cards.

The game is remarkably similar to Castle Risk. There are, however, several differences -some of them rather substantial- between the two games. Just to describe a few of them (comprehensive list here):

     The game's objectives (wining conditions) are different: Total conquest in Castle Risk vs a prefixed amount of conquests (Fully occupy 3 Empires in addition to your own) in RisiKo! Più.
     "Spoils"/Reinforcements are to be reclaimed, in RisiKo! Più, in the beginning of each round, while in Castle Risk this is done at the end of the round instead.


—user summary

Old Town Road is an in-hand solo card game following your encounters with outlaws along the infamous road leading to Old Town.

On your turn, you’ll use an action on one of your 6 face up cards, shooting targets or robbing banks to flip cards to increase VPs or to put cards to the back of your deck creating sequences of 3-card poker hands, worth VPs at the end of the game. At the end of the game, you’ll calculate your score by adding up points for each of your poker sequences as well as VPs for wanted posters and bank robberies.

The game is composed of 24 character cards, 4 establishment cards, and the Old Town reference card.

This matching-sets-for-points game is quick to learn and provides hours of play. Each card has a point value, with big game yielding more points than smaller game. The highest points go to the trophy rack buck. It’s a rare catch in this forest with only 2 available to hunt.

Each round players draw a card, create sets of cards to place down in front of them for scoring, and discard. A round ends when a player discards their last card. Any cards that are on the table in front of each player counts towards their score. Any cards left in their hand go against their score.

The first player to reach 1000 cumulative score, wins the game.

-description from publisher

Chaotic Studio is a drawing game that challenges players’ ability of image segmentation and deduction.

According to chosen subject, each player must prepare a specific drawing in three parts on three separate transparent cards respectively. Then, other players try to guess what the Subject is when one of the three parts is revealed and the other two are displayed in a mix with other drawings scattered on the table!

The longer it takes anyone to guess the Subject correctly, the more victory points (VP) the Active Player (the drawer) will score. However, the Active Player will gain no VP at all if no one guesses correctly.

A tactical board game of flying foxes and levitating islands.

Guide your pirate clan to victory by looting merchants, forging trade routes and wrestling control of the skies from your enemies.


BACKSTORY:

The cloud fox clans have always been divided, proving their dominance in tests of might, guile and flying prowess — but they never knew true conflict, until the humans came.

Seeking the magical wood of the Takka trees, which endows the Floating Isles and their giant fox denizens with the ability to levitate, the merchants built a vast fleet of sky ships. Swarming over the islands like a pestilence, they established ports, seized resources and displaced the cloud foxes.

You are the leader of a cloud fox clan and have allied with a band of human outlaws to take back your homeland. With the other clans competing for their share, will you be top fox in the new order?

GAMEPLAY:

The game takes place on a 6x6 grid. Roll three dice and assign one to select a row on the grid. Assign a second dice to select a column and the third dice determines what type of fox tile you get to place.

Each fox tile has an ability that activates immediately when placed as well a 'Control' value which determines how much control you have over the adjacent islands. Whoever has the most control over an island at the end of the game will score Vulpis Points (VP) for it.

You can also score VP for looting merchant ships and trading the resources with the matching ports at the end of the game.

—description from the publisher

Dennis Rehbein is a local politician of the German town Hagen.

Each of the 23 square cards shows 4 pictures in a grid 2 by 2. Each picture shows one of 4 politicians of the CDU (German party). Before the game begins, each player chooses one of these politicians. 3 mission cards face up show each an arrangement of several pictures. On your turn, draw a card and add it to the display. If you meet the condition(s) with your politician, you collect 1, 2 or 4 victory points for the according mission card(s). The player who reaches 12 victory points, wins.

—user summary

Roll for Great Old Ones: In this cooperative roll & write game set in the Lovecraft universe 1-4 investigators must work together against ancient evil powers.

Roll for Great Old Ones is a unique game in which players draft dice out of a general pool to program actions on their investigator board. Thus leaving behind "cultist dice", which will trigger actions during the scenario.
The investigators have to negotiate which dice to use and which to leave behind, knowing quite well what might happen.

In this cooperative game you will use dice to program actions, collect experience, earn free actions, learn powerful skills, use asymmetric powers and help each other to beat the evil cultists.
As a team you will have to work together to find all necessary clues before the cultists can successfully perform the ritual and our beloved world is doomed.

You either win together or seal the fate of all mankind!

—description from the designer

In this trick taking deck builder game you will be building your own personal deck to be then used to take tricks. Be the first person to win enough tricks to win.

—description from the designer

In å¤§æˆ¦äº‰ã®ã‚ã¨ã—ã¾ã¤ (Daisensou no Atoshimatsu), roughly "Cleaning Up the Mess After a Great War", players take on the role of political superpowers aiding in a fictional war.

It is a trick avoidance game, which is to say a trick-taking game where the aim is generally to not win tricks, as most will lose points for the winner.  However, the winner of a trick will place one of their flags on a market futures board where they will guess the icons on cards the players discarded to a face down pool at the start of the hand.  If accurate, these pay offs can make up for the points lost during the trick play.

After one hand, the player with the most points wins.

The front of each card has a top and a bottom showing different suits and ranks.

The lights come up. The bell rings. Minutes ago you were in a sweat-drenched locker room; now you’re in the centre the ring, fending off attacks from a glistening muscleman with a fish for a head. This is the Glorious Wrestling Alliance - and you’re the newest addition to the roster!

Glorious Wrestling Alliance: Ultrabrawl is a fast-and-frantic card game for 2-4 players that captures all the honour, passion and pageantry of the squared circle. Based on the comics of the same name, Ultrabrawl sees players assume the roles of one of six GWA combatants as they slug it out in their mission to be crowned champion!

Players play move cards in order to chain together combos, deal damage to their opponents and woo the crowd - all in service of nabbing that all-elusive pinfall. Cards will be drawn, dice will be rolled, egos will be bruised and crushing finishing manoeuvres will be deployed, as the GWA’s faintly ridiculous combatants chop, kick and suplex their way to victory!

—description from the designer

Qwixx has existed for ten years, and to celebrate Qwixx: 10 Jahre Limited-Edition is a special edition of the game that includes the Qwixx base game, as well as the Bonus and Gemixxt expansions and the components needed for the Qwixx Longo standalone game. All of the boards are erasable, and the game includes dry-erase markers.

Take a trip back in time as you roll the dice and find the dinosaur that matches the colour and pattern that was rolled. The first player to fill up their scene with dinosaurs and do their best dino roar is the winner!

Not only is this game educational, it will test Colour, number and pattern recognition as well as coordination and reflexes.

The player boards feature simple facts about the dinosaurs in the game too, it also includes a golden dinosaur trophy to award to the winner!

—description from the publisher

It’s the adult card game you can’t refuse. Based on the original 1972 The Godfather Italian movie starring Marlon Brando and Al Pacino, Last Family Standing is the ultimate adult game. Just when you thought you were out… they pull you back in. Will your family have power over them all?

Play from a hand of cards that allow you to form strategic alliances with the exchange of a rose. Perform actions that have you diving behind cars for cove or take aim at your opponents to gain power and take on other players’ Dons. The last player standing in this fun game will be in charge.

This adult board game is easy to get the hang of and only takes 30 minutes to play. For adults and teens ages 14 and up, get a group of 3-6 people together to play this family game for kids and adults. Play from a hand of cards that will allow you to bump off other players, duck behind a car, make alliances, and run off to Las Vegas or Italy. The player who is the last standing (still has at least 1 orange) wins!  Remember, it’s not personal. It’s strictly business.

Assemble your friends and set off on a unique co-operative, role play, story driven adventure into The Unseen world: a spiritual battleground where you and your team of Word Wielders take on hordes of demonic afflictions. Strategize and fight back the armies of darkness to expose the Monarchs of Doubt, Guilt, Fear, Sickness, Suffering, and Hatred. These Strongholds of ever-present lies must fall!

This game includes 9 different Word Wielder heroes to choose from, each with their own unique set of Gifts (abilities) from 4 different Classes: Champions (Melee/Tank), Seekers (Range/Bow & Arrows), Edifiers (Prayer Type Weapons/Words of Holy Fire and Healing Light), or Discerners (Dynamic & Well-rounded/weapon specializations are player’s choice).

Play through The Story (main campaign) that is broken out into 7 Chapters meant to be experienced over multiple sessions. Each Chapter can take between 60-90 minutes to complete. There are Checkpoints provided to help you pick up where you left off even if you put the game away.

Gameplay alternates between Two Phases:
One - The Chosen Phase where player’s spend their chosen Word Wielder’s Guidance Prayer and Action tokens to prepare for and battle The Darkness by rolling dice and comparing results against the enemy stats, and advance the Chapter objectives and
Two - The Darkness Phase where the Darkness on the board then takes their Actions trying to Burden and Overwhelm the Word Wielders in order to stop them.

So equip yourselves for battle by praying for Discernment, allowing you to draw from over 90 cards packed with anointed Weapons of Light, Armor, and Single-Use items. Each new card collected has its own abilities offering your Word Wielders limitless combinations and tactical possibilities. Slay the Darkness and collect their cards to build up a Light Pool - once enough enemies have been slain, return them to the Darkness Deck and draw a Heaven’s Armies Card with one of three different Angels that can be played to help your Wielders gain the advantage in battle. Work together to overcome the Darkness!

Get swept away in over two hours of intense, fully-narrated, audio dramas that bring each chapter of the game to life; drawing you into an epic journey you won’t soon forget. These can be found and listened to for free on the game’s official website.

Once you’ve played through the epic campaign you can continue your adventures in 7 nonlinear alternate game modes, each introducing new stories, objectives, and ways to play.

(PVP) Or, if you’re looking for something more classically competitive but with a twist, step on to The Sea of Glass (flip side of the board), for a bright and colorful map made for fast paced, lighthearted, head-to-head combat where you can compete against one another in 4 more game modes where it’s a race towards the objectives while Refining each other along the way through inevitable encounters.

With so many different variables and ways to play, no two games are ever the same…

Go, and know that He is with you!

—description from the publisher

The Seal Of Pragon is a traditional-style solitaire card game that only requires a single deck of standard playing cards (with two Jokers). The layout for this game looks roughly like a five-pointed star. The goal of this game is to remove all cards from the table by creating poker hands.

A clever array of action bonuses are afforded the player for every poker hand achieved. Examples include everything from removing cards to accessing the discard pile (helping to prolong the game).

The title for this game comes from its loose backstory. As stated by the designer "It roughly involves the player being part of an ancient order trying to break a seal which will unleash an ancient evil if it is not broken before dawn."

The Seal Of Pragon was a 2013 Print & Play Contest entry.

Can robot dream too ? With your workshop, take part in the wonderful MECH A DREAM project.

Each day is divided into 3 shifts where you can use your workers  

     Day 
     Afternoon 
     Evening


Depending on the time of the day, the workers will be more or less efficient. 
 
     Use your workers to collect steam and electricity 
     Use these resources to build machines 
     Use your machines to build dreams!


—description from the publisher

The great Abu Simbel temple hides a thousand-year-old secret. Its chambers patiently wait for someone brave enough to explore them. However, as every amazing adventure, the path is filled with dangers. The walls of the temple hide deadly traps that range from sharp blades to floors that collapse under your feet. And even poisonous scorpions and undead mummies! Do you dare explore the ancient secrets of Abu Simbel?

Abu Simbel is a board game you play on your feet, recreating the movements indicated by the cards to avoid the numerous traps hidden in the temple. If you decide to enter the chambers of the Abu Simbel temple, you will have to crawl, jump, squeeze through tight cracks, cross over dark pits and defeat the mummies that protect the temple! You will have to do it literally — moving your arms, hands, and legs.

The goal of Abu Simbel is to get past the traps in the different chambers in order to reach the great treasure vault, grab some treasures, and leave the temple through the same traps again, but in reverse and in total darkness!

At the end of the game, the winner is the player who scores the most points from the treasures gained and their remaining charm cards.

Discover the planets and be the first to complete your space mission!

Simply draw a card to discover a planet, and place it in the correct location in your solar system. The first astronaut to complete their solar system wins!

Children learn skills such as turn-taking, counting and strategy, and get to laugh at each other's silly alien impressions! They can also learn simple facts about each planet as they play.

—description from the publisher

There are thousands of possibilities in this game of connections! Simply place one hexagonal tile next to another and shout a word or phrase that connects the two illustrations.

For example; a tile with a bed and a tile with a person walking could be joined to make 'sleep walking'

You can even match with multiple tiles for a big bonus! Each tile can be interpreted in multiple ways, providing lots of play value. Gain a bonus turn by connecting tiles that have matching coloured backgrounds.

Can you be the first to get rid of all your tiles in this easy-to-pick-up picture game and claim victory!

—description from the publisher

A free print and play quick-playing entry level American Civil War wargame for 2 players, playable in 2 hours, where the intention is to have a core set of rules with which to play a number of different battles/scenarios.

The units are generic, so only need to be printed once. Each map and scenario card is a different battle. The first of which is Stones River.

—description from the designer

In Cães POP - Battle for Likes players are gathering likes playing pop dogs card's as internet influencers to gain followers. 
  
In the start of the game, players get 3 cards. In each turn, the player must discard a card to do an action, and take cards until reach 3 cards on hand.

Actions:


     Receive a Like: If playing dogs cards that is on focus.  
     Change focus: If playing dogs card's that doesn't is on focus  
     Do some especial effect: If playing cat cards. 


When you reach 5 likes Token or more, you can exchange immediately 5 likes Tokens to 1 Follower Token.

When one player reach 2 likes (3 in 4 players, 4 in 3 players, 5 in 2 players) this player win.

-description from designer

This is a mint tin game in the style of a light cube rails train game. Players collectively operate railway companies to increase company's worth and gain funds. Players can use funds to buy stock which is used at the end of the game to pay dividends out to determine the winner.

The theme is a Western theme with fictional train companies. The game is 1-4 players. The game can be played solo with a bot deck that is used to control the 2nd player.

On a player's turn, they can either 

     Buy stock
     Lay track


When laying track, the companies worth will increase and stock price decrease. So players need to find a balance when laying track.

—user summary

Elements consists of cards with two properties: the element (earth, water, air, fire) and the shape (circle, triangle, square, pentagon). There are also Single Cards with only one property and the rare Element Cards that can transform into any card.

Each player starts with eight random cards. The first card from the drawing pile gets turned over and the players continue the series. The first player who has laid out all of their cards wins the game.

In their turn, a player can lay out as many cards as they want as long as the element or the shape from the top card is continued. Once made, the decision between element or shape cannot be changed while laying out cards (For example: A water circle is the top card. The player lays out a water circle and then a fire circle. With the fire circle they chose "shape" and are able to lay out earth or air circles but no other shapes).

If a player is unable to lay out any card, they draw three cards and the direction of the game changes. This enables the players to make strategic decisions on which cards to lay out and in what order.

—description from the designer

Llamageddon is an ultralight party game of communication and persuasion for 3-6 players who are trying to survive the impending alpacalypse.

The llama homeworld of Planet Fluffrica is in imminent danger—and it’s your job to select survivors to preserve its culture. A huge meteor will soon strike the planet, obliterating it, along with all the highly-evolved llamas who call it home. Well, all except the lucky few elected to board a huge spaceship and escape the coming alpacalypse. To win, you’ll need to convince the other players to vote for the unique llamas you’ve selected for the mission; feel free to use logic, flattery, promises, veiled threats, and any other persuasive technique at your disposal. Get your llamas on board, leverage their secret characteristics, secure the most Llama Points, and escape before the fiery end!

The objective of the game is to collect Llama Points by getting your chosen llamas onto the spaceship using your communication skills. The game is played in rounds which consist of the following phases: Nomination, Discussion, Voting, Boarding & Characteristics. If, during the Characteristics Phase, the ship becomes full, the game ends, and the player with the highest LP total wins.

-description from publisher

The Cold Case game line summons players to investigate the unsolved cases of victims murdered decades ago by piecing together the details that the police could never find. Inside the box, you will find realistic materials pertaining to the crime, and a complex story containing everything you need to crack the case. Follow the clues and submit your answers online to finally bring the killers to justice.

In Murder with Interest, players investigate a double murder that takes place at an office party in a small town in Ireland.

In Rainforest, your aim is to create a jungle environment that offers a rich variety of vegetation, which will allow you to reintroduce and protect the region’s iconic species: Monkeys, frogs, butterflies and parrots. Don’t forget to secure the long-term survival of your totem animal, and you’ll be able to earn some precious extra points. Can you make your jungle a cradle of diversity?

After your dwarf clan found gold, you suddenly felt an earthquake and the mine is now collapsing. Time to escape! But the dark cave is full of dangers, such as spider webs, monsters, and of course the saboteurs who make your life miserable. Whose dwarf team can escape the cave with the most gold?

Saboteur: The Dark Cave is a standalone game that recreates the feel of Saboteur. At the start of the game, each player assigned to a clan, although possibly they will be a saboteur for the other clan. Starting from the mine card in the center of play, you take turns laying down tunnel cards to build outward from the mine toward the four corner cards, only one of which is the exit. In addition to building new tunnels, you'll play cards to give yourself equipment, place monsters in front of others, discover who's actually on your clan, and reveal the exit before trudging all the way there. As soon as you leave the mine, you reveal your true identity, with any gold you have going toward your clan's total. As soon as all members of a clan have left, the game ends, and whichever clan has the most gold wins.

Nephilim Fraternités is the first board game in the Nephilim rpg universe. 
It is a game of cooperation between Nephilim to face their ancestral enemies, secret societies, while trying to acquire as much esoteric knowledge as they can. It takes place in past incarnation periods.
The game play is a mix of dice/worker placement where each player has a dice pool they use to start actions on the game board. Each action is linked to an element and can either allow better fighting against the secret societies or progression in the quest for knowledge.

It’s last orders in the only saloon in town, and there’s more to kill than just time!
 Will the richest rancher in the Wild West be dead before sundown, or will you be able to save his skin?
 The year is 1885 and death will cast its shadow over the quiet town of Ghost Creek unless your sleuthing skills are able to stop it! Inside the Last Chance Saloon, six people nurse their drinks, each lost in thought. A traveling fortune teller decides to stop and quench her thirst. Suddenly, she’s struck with a vision: Avery Rogers – Ghost Creek’s richest man – will be dead by the end of the day, and at the hands of someone in the saloon! Set in the Wild West, this murder mystery will immerse you and your dinner guests in a world of revenge, blackmail and bandits! Will you be able to unravel the clues and motives to pinpoint the would-be murderer, all before coffee is served?

-description from publisher

Leave your moral compass at the door and find out what your friends think of you with this outrageous game that’ll get you naming and shaming!

Players take turns to read out a card with a “Most likely to” or “Least likely to” scenario, then vote on which player they think best fits that description.

Discover who needs to rethink their life choices in this game of naming and shaming!

A game of no winners, but one loser. You don't want to be deemed the trashiest!

—description from publisher

Within Stock Monarchy you will play as the ruler of a small Kingdom listed on the stock market. The competition will be relentless. To win, players must bring their Kingdom to dominate the stock market with a savvy combination of warfare, technology and trade.

THE STOCK STATES
The Stock States are a rich empire with a bizarre form of government: a stock monarchy. The Supreme Sovereign wields absolute power, but his election and term in office are determined by the satisfaction of the stockholders, the true masters of the Land.

CORONATION CHALLENGE
The time has come to nominate a new Supreme Sovereign. As usual, the Coronation Challenge is issued so as to find the most talented contestant amongst the richest Houses of the Realm. The winner of the Challenge will be crowned Ruler of the Stock States.
The Challenge will take place on one of the peripheral and uncivilized islands of the empire. The Island is inhabited by Mattoks, somewhat obtuse and naïve creatures with a very basic lifestyle. Mattoks can’t quite discern between good and evil and are therefore easy to manipulate or to corrupt. They are not to be entrusted with complex tasks, but they are excellent at following simple instructions and will comply with whatever command in exchange for a few shiny coins.
At the beginning of the Challenge every participant will be assigned a starting region of equal dimension and three months’ time to showcase their strategic skills and – most important of all – to enrich the stockholders.
The management of the Realms on the Island mirrors the stock monarchy of the Stock States: each scion will be free to act as an authentic absolute monarch, but his choices will be evaluated by the stock market. Dominating the market, however, will not be easy: all shareholders ultimately desire to grow richer and see the value of their shares rise, but some of them also have specific preferences on how this should be done. The two most prominent examples are definitely the conqueror and pioneer currents. The conquerors want a Ruler in power who pursues profit through military expansion, while the pioneers prefer one who will enrich them by investing in technological growth. Therefore, whoever wants to sit on the Throne of the Stock States will not only have to effectively administer his own Realm, but will also have to distribute copious dividends and support, at least in part, the interests of conquerors and pioneers. Ultimately, the winner of the Coronation Challenge will be the Ruler who is able to impose himself on the market and make the value of the shares of his Realm soar.

GAME-FLOW
The Game-Flow has 3 stages: Setup, Round and End Game.

SETUP
• Creating the island: the Island is created, depending on the number of Players (in a 2-Player game it is possible to create more
than 2 billion different Map layouts, in a 4 Player game more than a trillion, and that's without counting Resources and Know-How Tokens).
• Auctioning the Starting Territories: Players bid to seize the best possible starting Territory for their Realms.
• Setting up the Realms: every Ruler autonomously chooses the initial Setup of their Realm.

ROUND
• 3 Game Rounds: The 3 Game Rounds is where the real action takes place. The Kings have to plan and implement their strategies by issuing orders to the Spies and Mattoks of their own Realm. This is done through the 14 Command Cards, which let Players move their Spies and carry out Actions with the Mattoks.

END GAME
• Distributing dividends to the shareholders: the Money, Ingots and revenue from the sale of White Whiskey are used to pay
dividends, which drives up the value of the shares of the Realm.
• Announcing the winner: the Player whose shares have reached the highest value is crowned as new Supreme Sovereign of the Stock States.

-description from designer

In Chicken Hunter, players simultaneously reveal cards from their hand, aiming to score points.   There are no restrictions on what cards players can reveal (e.g. does not need to be a straight, or x-of-a-kind).

In each round, two hands will be rewarded with points.  First, look at the players who revealed the fewest number of cards.  This player earns points equal to the number of cards they revealed multiplied by the sum of the face value of these cards.  (In the case of a tie, the tied players first discard one card each.)

Then, from the remaining players, look at the player with the lowest face value sum of the cards revealed.  This player scores points using the same calculation.

Afterwards, players draw up to 6 cards and repeat the process.

The game lasts until a player achieves a preset threshold and at that point the person with the most points wins.

West of Souls is innovative solo or cooperative fantasy adventure for 1-6 players. Enter the world of Eloria, plagued by darkness and monsters of a vitriolic nature. You and your party will explore and make decisions that directly affect the world’s infrastructure and future. The vastly branching storylines and numerous NPCs found in West of Souls ensure unique game play and future replay ability.

Enemy encounters and agonizing choices abound in this game and even the simplest of decisions may alter the world as you know it. Players will take up the mantle of an unlikely hero who, through motives of their own, have decided to stop Eloria’s impending doom. Be it gold, valor, or a deep empathy for the world around them, the players must work together to gain victory over scenarios and continue on their journey.

As players progress through the ever-changing world, they will develop their abilities, gain increasingly effective gear, and unlock additional skills specific to their character. Following each completed scenario, player choices will determine the future direction of the party’s quest, guaranteeing player involvement in the development of their own story. 
 The game is split into scenarios that are comprised of an exploration and journey phase, and each turn is split into a time of day (morning, mid-day, dusk, night). In the journey phase of the game, characters with travel throughout the game map discovering locations, triggering events, battling monsters, interacting with the world, and talking with NPCs to gain information about their quest and Eloria’s tainted past. Action point-based turns are used within West of Souls. Each player will have a defined number of actions that may be completed on their turn (unless you have unlocked a skill or found some gear that says otherwise). Once enough information has been gathered and players are in the correct location, the exploration phase begins.

One unique aspect of West of Souls is that the exploration phase is a hybrid of non-linear narrative, card-based battle encounters, and dungeon crawling. In addition, all characters in play do not have to enter the same exploration together, allowing for multiple explorations to occur simultaneously. Within the exploration phase, players will be forced to make harrowing choices, complete skill checks, and defeat beast to move forward. Vital story elements, lore, and history will be revealed to the players as they progress through the game.  
While death is an option in West of Souls, a player is never permanently removed from the game. The main resources in this epic journey are time and stress. If your team does not accomplish their goal within the allotted time frame, Eloria is cast into ruin. Likewise, if the encounters prove too much for your party and your stress level reaches a breaking point, you will lose the game. Victory is achieved at the end of each scenario as players defeat enemies of increasing difficultly and complete the necessary tasks. 
 This flagship game from Sky Monster Games is an ambitious story telling odyssey that maximizes the use of battle mechanics in combination with non-linear storytelling and character customization.

-description from designer

In Roll & Write Railroads, the players are new employees of a railroad company, having just left their families' bean farms.  They were so good at running the bean farm, they were put in charge of all of the railroad projects. However, they have no knowledge of railroads!  So they made a die out of a soybean their parents entrusted them with, and leave their fate up to it.

On a turn, a player rolls one more dice than the number of players.  Then, in clockwise order, each player selects a die.  The players then take an action based upon the die number.  The actions involve laying track, building stations, and possibly gaining money.  Later, players may unlock ways to enhance these actions.

Players may only build from left to right, and only on train lines they have opened.

After each player finishes their actions, they each take a second action with the unselected die.  Then, the players score points based upon how far their stations have been built on each line.

After ten rounds, players sum their intermediate scores and also earn points for how many of their actions they enhanced.  The player with the most points wins.

Marvel Lucha Libre Edition characters fight one another, with a combination of luck and strategy to win 3 falls, and be the last "Rudo" or "Técnico" standing in the ring.

Roll dice to move your pawn, and if you land in a space with a wrestler from another player, you enter the ring... use one of your characters cards, then add the roll of your dice to see who comes out on top, win 3 falls and eliminate that wrestler. Last wrestler standing wins!

With 2 modes to play... Amateur and Pro Wrestler.

A competitive fast-paced dungeon crawling game for two to four players.  Game plays in 30-45 minutes.

Each game begins with a maze generated from randomly drawn dungeon cards.  The players take turns exploring and moving through the maze.  They can play cards from their hand to replace explored tiles to make it easier for them to escape or hinder the competing players.

The first to recover the magical Chalice and escape is the winner.

Play one of four different characters with unique attack and defense abilities to help you survive the minotaur’s fury.

-description from publisher

Daiquiri is a middle-weight domino climbing game for 3 or 4 players.

You will need 3 or 4 sets of double-six dominoes depending on the number of players.

There are no teams; it’s every person for themselves. Your score will depend solely on the position you go out so go out early.

A mouth-watering party game that lets you compete to cook some of the most iconic hawker dishes in Singapore.

Each player owns a hawker stall. On every player's turn, the player draws two ingredient cards and one action card. Then they take up to two of the following actions: (a) COOK: Cook a dish by matching the ingredients on hand with ingredients on the Dish card. Each dish is worth a certain number of points, (b) ACTION: Play an action card, or (c) TRADE: Trade 2 ingredients on hand with 1 ingredient from the Black Market

The first player that reaches the target number of points wins.

-description from publisher's website

This is a Target exclusive edition which features brand new cards and can be played on its own or with MonsDRAWsity.

Those pesky monsters are at it again, and one of them's been spotted nearby! As a paranormal investigator, it's your job to sketch out this newest anomaly based on your witness's description, but be careful... they didn't get a good look, and it's up to you to fill in the blanks! This sketching party game will have the whole table laughing!

-description from publisher

Narcopolis is an immersive and competitive board game. The game is played in the South of United States during the year 2000. It's a tactical game with bluffing. You have to be diplomatic and play dirty. Players light on the interactions and have fun around the table. The goal of Narcopolis is to become the new boss of the town. To become the new Boss, you have to be the one with the highest rate of reputation at the end of the Game. The Game finishes either when someone arrive to 20 points of reputation or after 10 turns.

You will play one of 5 characters and will evolve within a city where you will have to attack, conquer and develop resources to gain reputation points. Bluffing, corruption and strategy are key elements of the game.You will have to build casinos, weapons and other resources specific to the gang world to take control of the city.

Each turn every player have to play 2 obligatory actions (take money and move) and can do 5 more actions (play or buy influence card, do or exchange job, develope new Business, conquer a new area by fighting or just Build up new Business, Buy or sale reputation point).  To take territories to an enemy you have to play a dice fight which include a bluffing part. Every round turn the first player will revel a new event card which changes the game that round.

-description from writer

Meeple Detective is a deduction game that players must compete with other players to trace and apprehend Phantom and his minions.

The game have 2 PHASES :

ACTION PHASE
1. Each player must flip 1 card face up permanently and peek adjacent 1 card.

2.Check what type of card the player has last faced up.
2.1 If a face up card is a hostage room card or the clue room card : Nothing happened then next player will continue to play.
2.2 If a face up card is an event room card, active player must draw 1 time card and check what type of card opened is: 
> investigate : Enter the investigative phase.
> empty room : Nothing happened then next player will continue to play.

INVESTIGATION PHASE
1. Starting from active player. Each player may place their Meeple (s) on any room card or pass.
2. If you are a first player of that card, place 1 Meeple, if not, place 2 Meeples.
3. When it comes back to active player, INVESTIGATION PHASE end.

Game end immediately after complete investigation phase 4 times. Then, scoring begins. Player with the most points wins.

—description from the designer

This is the "Expanded Edition" which was originally available on Kickstarter. It comes with two expansions, the Emigration and Arsenic Expansion, that are not found in the retail edition. They can be obtained in Tinners' Trail: Expansions Box.


In Tinners' Trail, set in 19th century Cornwall, you represent a mining conglomerate at the height of the tin and copper mining industry. You must buy plots of land across Cornwall in auctions and survey them for tin and copper, always managing your "work points" and money effectively.

Once you have a mine in place, it's time to extract the ore and (ideally) make a profit, but the deeper your mine goes, the more expensive the process gets. To reduce the cost of mining, you can place developments, such as ports, train stations, and adits (drainage tunnels), but there's only so many improvements to go around. Once you have made your money — trying to time the market to sell when prices are high — you can invest it in industries outside of Cornwall, which gains you victory points. The earlier you invest, the better the return. Can you outplay the competition and make the most money, or will you be left without two shillings to rub together?

What's changed since 2008?
Increased player count - a game that was once only 3-4 players can now be enjoyed by 1-5 players!

2 new expansions - the Arsenic expansion, which introduces a new resource, and the Emigration expansion, which sees miners travel overseas.

Reduced randomness - but still keeping the variability. The board is now set up with tiles instead of the roll of a the dice.

Improved Auctions - dual-use cards are now an important part of the game, giving you information before an auction or an extra boost after an auction.

Improved artwork and graphic design

Improved component quality - with custom meeples and colour blind friendly colours.

Lord Wallace solo mode - a brand new solo mode.

Take control of one of six unique Corporations and vie for dominance in the Alpha System by utilizing a mix of different actions and resources. Focus on building up your infrastructure and set yourself up for a strong finish or go for fast and immediate rewards. Use your Influence in the council chamber to make sure things progress according to your wishes, or resort to outright aggression to dominate the competition.

A New Frontier is a highly engaging conflict game where your ability to gauge your opponents is key to victory. Since players can interact with all other players, regardless of position, conflicts are plentiful, but also quite undramatic. There is no player elimination, and you also cannot “gang-up” on someone, at least not from a conflict perspective. Conflicts are multi-phased, with ample opportunity to outsmart your opponents.

A New Frontier has nearly no hidden info (the obvious exception being player fleets) and few random elements, and with only 5 turns every decision counts. The goal of the game is to become the most dominant Corporate Republic in the Alpha System, which is achieved by having the most Victory Points by game’s end. All types of actions can potentially lead to Victory Points allowing for multi-pronged strategies. In addition to Actions and Credits, players must balance Prestige, which represents their organization’s goodwill and reputation, and that is essential for certain aspects of the game.

The game is centered around four ore-rich planets, with each player being present at every planet. This is where players harvest ore for income, build ships and upgrade mines, as well as carry out attacks against each other. In addition, there are four support areas/phases (Exploration, Politics, Marketing and R & D), where players can choose to diversify in order to gain advantages and Victory Points. Each Turn starts with a Planning Phase where players hiddenly set their strategic plan for the whole turn by using the resources at their disposal. Players then make tactical decisions during each Action Phase within the framework of their strategic plan.

Depending on chosen strategy, a player will normally amass between 30-60% of their Victory Points during the game, and the rest during end game scoring.
